monogr.author: Francis Beaumont
John Fletcher
monogr.title: Comedies and Tragedies Written by Francis Beavmont and Iohn Fletcher, Gentlemen. Never printed before, And now published by the Authours Originall Copies.

imprint.pubPlace: The Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church-yard

front.head: This character list has been adapted from the 1679 folio edition of Beaumont and Fletcher's Fifty Comedies and Tragedies. Spelling has been regularized based on how names appear in the dialogue and speech prefixes, and new descriptions have been supplied.

castItem.roleDesc: ship's officer in charge of equipment and the crew
French Lord looking to buy land and lordship in a new country; banished from his country
a woman aboard the ship; under the protection of Albert
leader of the female commonwealth; a firm protector of the commonwealth
daughter of Rosella; raised by only women (aka, the commonwealth)

div.note: Thunder and lightning: In early modern plays, the stage direction "thunder and lightning" was very common, and the effects of thunder and lightning produced in a variety of different ways. In this play, it's assumed that the stage direction "thunder and lightning" is directly linked to a storm (Dessen and Thomson, 231). Making the sounds of thunder and lightning could have been achieved through drums, flashes of fire, and fireworks. This type of effect was created in the tiring house. They were noted by the bookkeeper in the manuscript playbook used backstage so that he could cue for the effect at the right time (Thomson, 14). In many other plays, the effects of thunder and lightning were linked to the supernatural, and accompanied figures such as devils and witches, who might ascend from a trapdoor that signified the underworld. An audience would expect something supernatural when this particular effect occured (Thomson, 11).

lg.l: Lay her aloof aloof: to the windward side! The sea grows dangerous!
How it spits against the clouds, how it capers capers: dances or leaps,
And how the fiery element frights it back! Lightning.
There be devils dancing in the air, I think.
I saw a dolphin hang i'th' horns of the moon
Shot from a wave—Hey day! Hey day Hey day: exclamation!

How she kicks and jerks! How she kicks and jerks: It's important to remember that a performer in early modern plays could have expected to perform in a venue that was "a rectangular, flat, largely empty stage [with] no sets in the modern sense" (Syme, 112). Thus, we can assume that there was not actually a physical ship on stage. Therefore, in order to portray some sort of sea voyage, the use of ropes, tackle boxes, and other sailing equipment could have aided the impression of being at sea, with characters pulling on cords found in the tiring house. The stage was seen as the deck, the tiring house as the cabin of the ship, and the balcony as the mast or the lookout area. During this play, it's also clear that the characters on the boat are fighting against strong waves; this illusion could have been made by the characters acting wild and hysterical (McInnis, 118).
Down with the main mast, lay her at hull lay her at hull: float or drift with wind or current,
Furl up all her linens, and let her ride it out.
She'll never brook brook: tolerate it, Master.
She's so deep laden that she'll bulge bulge: spring a leak; also, swell.
Hang her.
Can she not buffet buffet: beat back, contend with with a storm a little?
How it tosses her! She reels like a drunkard.
We have discovered the land, sir.
Pray, let's make in. She's so drunk, else
She may chance to cast up cast up: vomit all her lading lading: cargo.
Land in, land in. We are all lost else, lost and perished.
Steer her astarboard there.
Bear in with all the sail we can. See, Master,

See! What a clap of thunder there is, The special effects used during live performances in early modern England would depend heavily on the budget of the playhouse; they could range from austere and simple to grand and elaborate (Syme, 112-14). Different effects such as drums, the firing of canons, and even fireworks could have been used to give the illusion that the actors and audience were actually in the center of a raging tempest. Thunder.
What a face of heaven; how dreadfully it looks! Sailor 2 looking up.
Thou rascal, thou fearful rogue, thou hast been praying,
I see't in thy face. Thou hast been mumbling
When we are split, you slave. Is this a time
To discourage our friends with your cold orisons orisons: prayers>?

Call up the boatswain boatswain: a ship's officer in charge of equipment.
Sailor 1 beckons Boatswain from off-stage. How it storms—holla holla: an exclamation calling for attention or to cease!
What shall we do, Master?
Cast over all her lading lading: cargo? She will not swim
An hour else.

div.stage: Enter Albert, Franville, Lamure, Tibalt Du-Pont, and Morillat.

lg.l: The storm is loud! Thunder and lightning.
We cannot hear one another!
What's the coast What's the coast: i.e. What coastline is it?
We know not yet. Shall we make in?
What comfort, sailors?
I never saw, since I have known the sea,
(Which has been this twenty years) so rude a tempest.
In what state are we?
Dangerous enough, Captain.
We have sprung five leaks, and no little ones—
Still rage—besides, her ribs are open,
Her rudder almost spent spent: used up, worn out. Prepare yourselves
And have good courages. Death comes but once,
And let him come in all his frights.
Is't not possible
To make in to'th' land? 'Tis here before us.
Here hard by hard by: very near, sir.
Death is nearer, gentlemen,
Yet do not cry. Let's die like men.
Shall's Shall's: Shall we hoist the boat out hoist the boat out: put out the rowboat
And go all at one cast at one cast: in one movement? The more the merrier.
You are too hasty, Monsieur.
Do ye long to be i'th' fish market before your time?
Hold her up there.
Oh, miserable fortune!
Nothing but horror sounding in mine ears,
No minute to promise to my frighted soul.
Peace, woman!
We ha' storms enough already; no more howling.
Gentle Master-
Clap Clap: Place in custody this woman under hatches hatches: half-doors on a deck.
Prithee, speak mildly to her.
Can no help?
None that I know.
No promise from your goodness?
Am I a god? For heaven's sake, stow this woman.
Go! Take your gilt gilt: thinly layered in gold prayer book
And to your business. Wink Wink: Close your eyes and die.
There an old haddock stays for ye There ... stays for ye: The implication is that fish wait for her in the ocean, or perhaps under decks (Bourne)..
Must I die here in all the frights, the terrors,
The thousand several shapes death triumphs in,
No friend to counsel me—?
Have peace, sweet mistress.
No kindred tears upon me—oh, my country!—
No gentle hand to close mine eyes?
Be comforted. Heaven has the same
Power still, and the same mercy.
Oh! That wave will devour me!
Carry her down, captain,
Or by these hands I'll give no more direction.
Let the ship sink or swim, we ha' ne'er better luck
When we ha' such stowage stowage: cargo as these trinkets with us,
These sweet sin-breeders. How can heaven smile on us
When such a burden of iniquity burden of iniquity: i.e. the stowage

Lies tumbling like a potion in our ship's belly? These sweet ... ship's belly?: The "sweet sin breeders" the shipmaster is referring to are women (here, specifically, Aminta, as she is the only woman on the boat). The shipmaster believes that everyone on the ship is going to die because they won't have any help from the heavens, and he blames this entirely on Aminta. Many times, women were denied passage on ships; if they happened to be on board, they were either a captive, a slave, or being forced to marry (Moore, 318). In Aminta's next speech below, it becomes clear that she has been captured by Albert, and that he has forced her to be on his ship for his own pleasure. Ironically, Aminta is only on the ship because of him, yet she is still being blamed for compromising the ability of the men to control the boat during the dangerous storm.

div.stage: Exit Master, Boatswain, Sailors, Morillat, Lamure, and Franville.

lg.l: Away with her, and if she have a prayer
That's fit for such an hour, let her say't quickly
And seriously.
Come. I see it clear, lady. Come in,
And take some comfort. I'll stay with ye.
Where should I stay? To what end should I hope?
Am I not circled round with misery?
Confusions in their full in their full: i.e. a more fully felt or accumulated heights dwell about me.
Oh, Monsieur Albert, how am I bound to curse ye

If curses could redeem me! How to hate ye! Oh, Monsieur ... to hate ye!: In the 1647 text of the play, question marks are used to punctuate "Oh ... redeem me" and "How ... ye," but sometimes, in the seventeenth century, compositors would use question marks where we would use exclamation points today (Jackson, 549). Thus, the lines (as presented here) illustrate Aminta's raging anger and hatred for Albert if the question marks are meant to be interpreted as exclamation points. Question marks in this scene give off a completely different meaning: they would account for Aminta's confusion as to whether she should curse and hate Albert. Regardless, one cannot be sure as to when Aminta exactly falls in love with Albert, but it's crucial to consider that she is his prisoner before their love blossoms.
You forced me from my quiet, from my friends—
Even from their arms—that were as dear to me
As daylight is, or comfort to the wretched.
You forced my friends from their peaceful rest.
Some your relentless sword gave their last groans—
Would I had there been numbered—
And to Fortune's never-satisfied afflictions
Ye turned my brother and those few friends I'd left
Like desperate creatures to their own fears
And the world's stubborn pitties. Oh, merciless!
Sweet mistress—
And whether they are wandered to avoid ye,
Or whether dead and no kind earth to cover 'em;
Was this a lover's part? But heaven has found ye,
And in his loud voice, his voice of thunder,
And in the mutiny of his deep wonders,
He tells ye now: ye weep too late.
Let these tears tell how I honor ye.
Ye know, dear lady, since ye were mine,
How truly I have loved ye, how sanctimoniously sanctimoniously: pure or holy in character
Observed your honor. Not one lascivious word,
Not one touch, lady—no, not a hope that might not render me
The unpolluted servant of your chastity.
For you I put to sea to seek your brother—
Your captain, yet your slave—that his redemption,
If he be living where the sun has circuit,
May expiate your rigor rigor: harshness, sternness and my rashness.
The storm grows greater. What shall we do?
Let's in,
And ask heaven's mercy. My strong mind yet presages presages: predicts, gives warning:
Through all these dangers, we shall see a day yet
Shall crown your pious pious: pitiful, devoted, faithful hopes and my fair wishes.

div.stage: Enter Master, Sailors, Gentlemen, Boatswain, and Surgeon.

lg.l:
It must all overboard.
Master pointing at goods.
It clears to seaward mast.
Fling o'er the lading lading: cargo there, and let's lighten her—
All the meat, and the cakes, we are all gone else—
That we may find her leaks and hold her up!
Yet save some little biscuit for the lady
'Til we come to the land.
Must my goods over too?
Why, honest Master? Here lies all my money,
The money I have wracked wracked: raked, i.e. accumulated; possibly also wrecked by usury usury: moneylending, often at excessive rates
To buy new lands and lordships in new countries
'Cause I was banished from mine own.
I ha' been this twenty years a-raising it.
Out with it.
The devils are got together by the ears got together by the ears: fallen out, gathered to fight who shall have it,
And here they quarrel in the clouds.

I am undone, sir. I am undone, sir.: On board this ship, there is a very interesting mix of characters from various social classes. Three of the men—Lamure, Franville, and Morillat—are French lords. In the early modern period, clothing helped establish a person's identity and located their position in a variety of categories ranging from gender, class, nationality, and religion (Lublin, 10). Thus, when Lamure's clothes and goods are thrown overboard, his response is that he feels completely ruined and destroyed (i.e. "undone"). Although this may seem dramatic to the modern reader, these characters experience a loss of material goods as a loss of identity. Furthermore, because Lamure is a self-made man (lines 137-140), he loses the noble identity he has created for himself (apparently by dubious means) and now fears being seen as equal to those of a lower class that he spent "twenty years" trying to buy his way out of.
And be undone. 'Tis better than we perish.
Oh, save one chest of plate plate: gold or silver coin!
Away with it lustily lustily: with pleasure or vigor, sailors—
It was some pawn that he has got unjustly—
Down with it low enough, and let crabs breed in't.

Over with the trunks too.
Master pointing at chests.
Take mine and spare not.
We must over with all.
Will ye throw away my lordship
That I sold, put it into clothes and necessaries
To go to sea with?
Over with it. I love to see a lordship sink.
Sir, you left no wood upon't to buoy it up.
You might have saved it, else.
I am undone forever.
Why, we are all undone. Would you be only happy?
Sir, you may lose too—
Thou liest. I ha' nothing but my skin,
And my clothes, my sword here, and my self, Tibalt pulling out sword.

Two crowns crowns: British coins with a value of five shillings in my pocket, two pair of cards,
Tibalt pulling goods out of pockets.

And three false dice. three false dice: Among Tibalt's listed possessions are "false dice," which are trick or weighted dice. Used as a prop, they are a physical manifestation for the actor to demonstrate the kind of wayward person that Tibalt is. And if the dice are not shown on stage and are instead just mentioned by name only, then it grants a quick snapshot of someone who values a handful of cheat dice as some of the things he keeps with him when he has so few possessions: "skin," "clothes," "sword," "self," "two crowns," "two pair of cards," and "three false dice" (lines 162-165). His possessions portray him as a kind of traveling vagabond, a drifter that goes town to town and makes a living by gambling and violence. I can swim like a fish,
Rascal, nothing to hinder me.
In with her of all hands of all hands: on the part of everyone.
Come, gentlemen; come captain; ye must help, all.
My life now for the land;
'Tis high, and rocky, and full of perils.
However, let's attempt it.
Then cheer lustily lustily: with pleasure or vigor, my hearts my hearts: term of address often used in consideration of bravery.
Yes, 'tis a ship! I see it now, a tall ship!
Heaven's mercy, what a wretched day has here been!
To still and quiet minds that knew no misery
It may seem wretched, but with us, 'tis ordinary.
Heaven has no storm in store, nor earth no terror,
That can seem new to us.
'Tis true, Nicusa, if Fortune Fortune: Roman goddess of luck were determined
To be wanton wanton: undisciplined, unjust, abnormal and would wipe out the stories
Of men's miseries. Yet we two living,
We could cross her purpose, for 'tis impossible
She should cure us. We are so excellent in our afflictions
It would be more than glory to her blindness blindness: Fortune was often depicted as veiled
And style her power beyond her pride to quit quit: leave us.
Do they live still?
Yes, and make to harbor.
Most miserable men. I grieve their fortunes.
How happy had they been had the sea covered 'em!
They leap from one calamity to another.
Had they been drowned they had ended all their sorrows.
What shouts of joy they make!
Alas, poor wretches. Had they but once experience
Of this island they'd turn their tunes to wailings.
Nay, to curses
That ever they set foot on such calamities.
Here's nothing but rocks and barrenness—
Hunger, and cold to eat—here's no vineyards
To cheer the heart of man, no crystal rivers
After his labor to refresh his body;
If he be feeble, nothing to restore him
But heavenly hopes. Nature that made those remedies
Dares not come here nor look on our distresses
For fear she turn wild like the place, and barren.
Oh, uncle, yet a little memory of what we were
'Twill be a little comfort in our calamities.
When we were seated in our blessèd homes,
How happy in our kindreds, in our families,
In all our fortunes!
Curse on those French pirates that displanted displanted: evicted, dislodged us,
That flung us from that happiness we found there,
Constrained Constrained: Forced, confined us to sea to save our lives, honors, and our riches
With all we had—our kinsmen and our jewels—
In hope to find some place free from such robbers,
Where a mighty storm severed our barks barks: wooden ships,
That, where my wife, my daughter,
And my noble ladies that went with her—
Virgins and loving souls—to 'scape those pirates—
They are living yet; such goodness cannot perish.
But never to me, cousin,
Never to me again. What bears their flag-staves? What bears their flag-staves: i.e. What flag does their ship fly?
The arms of France, sure—
Nay, do not start; we cannot be more miserable.
Death is a cordial cordial: comforting or reviving medicine or beverage now, come when it will.
They get to shore apace apace: quickly. They'll fly fly: flee as fast

When once they find the place. What's that which swims there? What's ... swims there?: "[T]here" might be accompanied by a gesture towards the audience. The architecture of the outdoor playhouses, with standing-room around the stage, meant that actors could gesture or look to the audience to create a sense of the imagined space of the sea or anything that is being referred to at a distance (Syme, 95).
A strong young man, sir, with a handsome woman
Hanging about his neck.
That shows some honor.
May thy brave brave: fine, worthy charity, what e'er thou art,
Be spoken in a place that may renown thee
And not die here.
The boat it seems turned over—
So forced to their shifts shifts: last extremities, great efforts—yet all are landed.
They're pirates, on my life.
They will not rob us
For none will take our misery for riches.
Come, cousin, let's descend and try their pities.
If we get off, a little hope walks with us,
If not, we shall but load this wretched island
With the same shadows still that must grow shorter.

div.stage: Enter Albert, Aminta, Tibalt, Morillat, Lamure, Franville, Master, Surgeon, and Sailors.

lg.l: Wet! Come ashore, my mates; we are safe arrived yet.
Thanks to heaven's goodness: no man lost!
The ship rides fair, too, and her leaks in good plight good plight: good condition.

The weather's turned more courteous.
Albert turning to Aminta.
How does my dear How does my dear: i.e. How are you?? Alas, how weak she is and wet!
I am glad yet: I 'scaped with life;
Which certain, noble noble: fine, good,captain next to heaven's goodness
I must thank you for; and which is more,
Acknowledge your dear tenderness, your firm love
To your unworthy mistress, and recant too
(Indeed, I must) those harsh opinions,
Those cruel, unkind thoughts, I heaped upon ye.
Farther than that, I must forget your injuries.
So far I am tied and fettered fettered: bound with fetters or chains to your service,
Believe me, I will learn to love.
I thank ye, madam;
And it shall be my practice to serve.—
What cheer What cheer: i.e. How do you feel,companions?
No great cheer, sir: a piece of soused soused: pickled biscuit
And half a hard egg, for the sea has taken order order: the sum total.
Being young and strong we shall not surfeit surfeit: suffer from overindulgence in food or drink , captain.
For mine own part, I'll dance 'til I'm dry.
Come, Surgeon , out with your clyster-pipe clyster-pipe: tube used to insert medicine into the rectum
And strike a galliard galliard: music to accompany a quick and lively dance; also, the dance itself.
What a brave brave: fine, worthy day again,
And what fair weather after so foul a storm!
Ay! An't pleased the Master, he might ha' seen
This weather and ha' saved our goods—
Never think on 'em; we have saved our lives and healths.
I must think on 'em and think:
'Twas most maliciously done to undo me—
And me, too; I lost all.
I haven't another shirt to put upon me, nor clothes
But these poor rags. I had fifteen fair suits;
The worst was cut upon taffety taffety: fine, crisp fabric of a plain weave.
I am glad you ha' lost. Give me thy hand—
Is this skin whole? Art thou not purled purled: covered in purl stitches with scabs?
No ancient monuments of Madam Venus Venus: Roman goddess of beauty and love?
Thou hast a suit, then, will pose pose: confuse, perplex the cunning'st tailor
That will never turn fashion nor forsake thee
'Til thy executors, the worms, uncase uncase: skin; also, undress thee;

They take off glorious suits suits: suits of clothing; also, a reference to the skin as the body's suit,
Franville; thou art happy
Thou art delivered of 'em. Here are no brokers,
No alchemists to turn 'em into metal

Nor leathered captains leathered captains: captains in military dress (Bourne). with ladies to adore 'em. Here are ... to adore 'em: Tibalt tries to defend Albert and the Captain's orders to discard the men's belongings for the safety of the crew. He challenges Franville by saying there is no one here to admire his suits, i.e. there are no people to impress with the fabrics they are made up of or how he looks while wearing them. Additionally, there is also no one there to buy his suits (i.e. to turn them into "metal," or coins). According to Tibalt, Franville's most important suit is his own body, specifically his skin.
Wilt thou see a dogfish rise in one of thy brave brave: fine, worthy doublets doublets: close-fitting jackets worn primarily by men
And tumble like a tub to make thee merry?
Or an old haddock rise with thy hatched sword hatched sword: light sword that can be used in one hand
Thou paid a hundred crowns crowns: British coins with a value of five shillings for?
A mermaid in a mantle mantle: robe or cloak of your worship's?

Or a dolphin in your double ruff? I am ... double ruff: Tibalt's monologue acts as a social commentary and revolves around how much importance noblemen gave to their material possessions, to the point where they evaluated their virtues and characters based on material goods. He begins by urging them to be grateful for having skin that is not corrupted by venereal disease ("purled with scabs"/"ancient monuments to Madam Venus"). Their skin, he continues, will never go out of fashion or abandon them until their bodies decayed after death and were devoured by worms. The purpose of this monologue is to acquaint the audience (and readers) with how social hierarchy was determined by material possessions by having Tibalt satirize the social practice. He suggests that having clothes represent our accomplishments as individuals is just as ridiculous as fish appearing in the clothes that have now sunk to the bottom of the sea.
Ye are merry, but if I take it thus,
If I be foisted foisted: cheated and jeered jeered: mocked out of my goods—
Nor I, I vow thee,
Nor Master, nor mate; I see your cunning.
Oh, be not angry, gentlemen.
Yes, sir, we have reason
And some friends I can make And some friends I can make: i.e. I can bring the others to my side.
What I did, gentlemen, was for the general safety.
If ye aim at me I am not so tame.
Pray, take my counsel, gallants gallants: men of fashion.
Fight not 'til the Surgeon be well;
He's damnable seasick, and may spoil all.
Besides, he has lost his fiddlestick fiddlestick: small instrument or insignificant item and the best
Box Box: Surgical cupping glass, or possibly lidded case for ointments of boar's grease. Why do you make such faces
And hand your swords?
Who would ye fight with, gentlemen?
Who has done ye wrong? For shame, be better tempered.
No sooner come to give thanks for our safeties
But we must raise new civil broils civil broils: communal conflicts amongst us,
Inflame those angry powers to shower new vengeance.
What can we expect for these unmanly murmurs,
These strong temptations of their holy pieties holy pieties: feelings of pity, devotion, and faithfulness,
But plagues in another kind, a fuller a fuller: i.e. a more fully felt or accumulated plague so dreadful
That the singing storms are slumbers in it?
Be men, and rule your minds.
If you will needs fight, gentlemen,
And think to raise new riches by your valors,
Have at ye; I have little else to do now.
I have said my prayers. You say you have lost
And make your loss your quarrel,
And grumble at my captain here, and the Master,
Two worthy persons—indeed, too worthy for such rascals,
Thou galloon galloon: gaily dressed gallant gallant: man of fashion , and Mammon Mammon: greedy person, you
That build on golden mountains, thou money maggot money maggot: i.e. one who feeds off money and material possessions,
Come all, draw your swords! Ye say ye are miserable— Tibalt drawing sword.
Nay, hold, good Tibalt.
Captain, let me correct 'em!
I'll make ye ten times worse—I will not leave 'em—
For look ye: fighting is as nourishing to me as eating,
I was born quarrelling.
Pray, sir—
I will not leave 'em skins to cover 'em!
Do ye grumble when ye are well, ye rogues?
Noble Noble: Fine, good du-Pont—
Ye have clothes now and ye prate prate: cluck, howl, or chatter!
Pray, gentlemen, for my sake be at peace.
Let it become me to make all friends.
You have stopped our angers, lady.
This shows noble noble: finely, splendidly; also, characteristic of behavior appropriate to noble status—
'Tis well, 'tis very well. There's half a biscuit:
Break't amongst ye all, and thank my bounty bounty: worth, virtue;
This is clothes and plate plate: gold or silver coin, too. Come, no quarrelling.
But ha! What things are these? Noticing Sebastian and Nicusa
Are they human creatures?
I have heard of sea-calves sea-calves: seals.
They are no shadows, sure; they have legs and arms.
They hang but lightly on, though.
How they look; are they men's faces?
They have horsetails growing to 'em,
Goodly long manes.
Alas, what sunk eyes they have!
How they are crept in as if they had been frighted!
Sure they are wretched men.
Where are their wardrobes?
Look ye, Franville; here are a couple of courtiers!
They kneel. Alas, poor souls.
What are ye? Speak! Are ye alive
Or wandering shadows that find no peace on earth
'Til ye reveal some hidden secret?
We are men as you are,
Only our miseries make us seem monsters.
If ever pity dwelt in noble hearts—
We understand 'em, too. Pray, mark mark: watch; pay attention to 'em, gentlemen.
Or that heaven is pleased with human charity,
If ever ye have heard the name of friendship
Or suffered in your selves the least afflictions,
Have gentle fathers that have bred ye tenderly
And mothers that have wept for your misfortunes,
Have mercy on our miseries!
Stand up, wretches.
Speak boldly and have release.
If ye be Christians
And by that blessed name bound to relieve us,
Convey us from this island.
Speak! What are ye?
As you are: gentle born. To tell ye more
Were but to number up our own calamities
And turn your eyes wild with perpetual weepings.

These many years These many years: Sebastian does not go into detail about how long he and Nicusa have been stranded on the island. Descriptions of their physical state and appearance, such as "goodly long manes" and "sunk eyes," provide some clues, but these details are not enough to indicate an exact number of years. The unspecified number of years opens up interpretation not only to how long the men have been stranded, but how long they have been separated from the Portuguese women. We later learn that enough time has passed for Clarinda, who seems to have come to the island as a very small child, to grow to sexual maturity. in this most wretched island
We two have lived. The scorn scorn: object of contempt and game of Fortune Fortune: Roman goddess of luck—
Bless yourselves from it, noble noble: fine, good gentlemen—
The greatest plagues that human nature suffers
Are seated here: wildness, and wants wants: shortages innumerable.
How came ye hither?
In a ship, as you do, and (as you might have been
Had not heaven preserved ye for some more noble more noble: better, finer use).
Wrecked desperately, our men and all consumed
But we two that still live and spin out
The thin and ragged threads of our misfortunes The thin ... misfortunes: from Greek mythology, referring to the threads of fate.
Is there no meat above?
Nor meat, nor quiet,
No summer here to promise anything
Nor autumn to make full make full: i.e. make more fully felt or accumulated the reaper's hands.
The earth, obdurate obdurate: resistant to influence, physically hard to the tears of heaven,
Lets nothing shoot shoot: germinate but poisoned weeds.
No rivers, nor no pleasant groves, no beasts;
All that were made for man's use fly fly: flee this desert.
No airy fowl dares make his flight over it
It is so ominous:

l.seg: Serpents and ugly things, the shames of nature,

lg.l: Roots of malignant malignant: damaging or harmful tastes, foul standing waters.

l.seg: Sometimes we find a fulsome fulsome: difficult to digest sea-root
And that's a delicate delicate: delicacy, a rat sometimes,
And that we hunt like princes in their pleasure.
And when we take a toad, we make a banquet

lg.l: For heaven's sake, let's aboard.
D'ye know no farther?
Yes, we have sometimes seen the shadow of a place inhabited
And heard the noise of hunters,
And we have attempted to find it. So far as a river—
Deep, slow, and dangerous, fenced with high rocks—
We have gone but, not able to achieve the hazard not able ... hazard: i.e. not able to cross the river,
Return to our old miseries.
If this sad story may deserve your pities—
Ye shall aboard with us; we will relieve your miseries.
Nor will we be unthankful for this benefit.

No, gentlemen, we'll pay for our deliverance.
Sebastian gesturing towards heaps.
Look, ye that plough plough: figuratively tilling fields, more generally a means of earning one's livelihood the seas for wealth and pleasures,
That outrun day and night with your ambitions,
Remove 'em and view 'em fully.
Oh, heaven, they are gold and jewels!
Be not too hasty; here lies another heap.
And here another!
All perfect gold—
Stand farther off. You must not be your own carvers carvers: those who apportion or carve meat at the table.
We have shares, and deep ones—
Yes, sir, we'll maintain't. Ho, fellow sailors!
Stand all to your freedoms;
I'll have all this—
And I this!
You shall be hanged, first!
My losses shall be made good!
So shall mine, or with my sword I'll do't.
All that shall share with us, assist us!
Captain, let's set in.
This money will undo us, undo us all.
This gold was the overthrow of my happiness.
I had command, too, when I landed here,
And led young, high, and noble noble: fine, splendid spirits under me.
This cursed gold enticing 'em, they set upon their captain—
On me that owned this wealth, and this poor gentleman—
Gave us no few wounds, forced us from our own.
And then their civil swords, who should be owners
And who lords over all, turned against their own lives:
First, in their rage consumed the ship—
That poor part of the ship that 'scaped the first wreck—
Next, their lives by heaps. Oh, be you wise and careful!
We'll ha' more, sirrah sirrah: contemptuous address used to men and boys , come show it—
Or ten times worse afflictions than thou speak'st of!
Nay, and ye will be dogs.

div.stage: Exit Albert, driving off Lamure and Franville.

lg.l: Let me come, captain.

This golden age must have an iron ending. This golden age ... iron ending: A reference to two of the five different ages of man from Greek mythology; the Golden Age was the first and best age. Iron refers to the last and worst age of mankind, signaling the transition of Albert's crew from a state of comfort and civility to a state of brutishness and toil. Also a reference to Tibalt's sword.
Tibalt draws his sword.
Have at the bunch!

div.stage: Exit Tibalt, driving off remaining French men.

lg.l: Oh, Albert! Oh, gentlemen! Oh, friends!
Come, noble noble: fine, good nephew. If we stay here, we die.
Here rides their ship, yet all are gone to'th' spoil spoil: valuable goods, i.e. Sebastian and Nicusa's gold.
Let's make a quick use.
Away, dear uncle.
This gold was our overthrow—
It may now be our happiness!

div.stage: Enter Tibalt and Albert, in pursuit of the rest.

lg.l: You shall have gold, yes: I'll cram it in't' ye!
You shall be your own carvers carvers: those who apportion or carve meat at the table, yes: I'll carve carve: apportion or carve meat at the table; here also referring to attacking with a sword ye!
I am sore; I pray, hear reason—
I'll hear none;
Covetous base base: low-born, not noble minds have no reason.
I am hurt myself, but whilst I have a leg left
I will so haunt your gilded souls. How d'ye, captain?
Ye bleed apace apace: quickly, curse on the causers on't;
D'ye not faint?
No, no, I am not so happy.
D'ye howl? Nay, ye deserve it,
Base Base: Low-born, not noble greedy rogues. Come, shall we make an end of 'em?
They are our countrymen. For heaven's sake, spare 'em.
Alas, they are hurt enough and they relent now.
Oh, captain, captain!
Whose voice is that?
The lady's.
Look, captain, look! Ye are undone, poor captain.
We are all undone; all, all, we are all miserable!
Mad, willful men, ye are undone! Your ship! Your ship!
What of her?
She's under sail and floating.
See where she flies! See to your shames, you wretches!
Those poor starved things that showed you gold—
They have cut the cables
And got her out. The tide, too, has befriended 'em.
Where are the sailors that kept her?
Here, here in the mutiny to take up money,
And left no creature; left the boat ashore, too!

l.seg: This gold, this damned enticing gold!

lg.l: How the wind drives her,
As if it vied to force her from our furies!
Come back, good old men—
Good honest men, come back!
The wind's against ye; speak louder!
Ye shall have all your gold again! They see us—
Hold up your hands, and kneel,
And howl, ye blockheads; they'll have compassion on ye;
Yes, yes, 'tis very likely! Ye have deserved it.
D'ye look like dogs now?
Are your mighty courages abated?
I bleed apace apace: quickly, Tibalt.
Retire, sir, and make the best use of our miseries;
They but begin now.

div.stage: Exit Aminta, Lamure, Franville, and Sailors

lg.l: Are ye alive still?
Yes, sweet.
Help him off, lady,
And wrap him warm in your arms—
Here's something that's comfortable—off with him handsomely handsomely: fittingly,
I'll come to ye straight, but vex these rascals a little.
Oh! I am hungry, and hurt, and I am weary.

Here's a pestle pestle: leg or haunch of an animal of a portague portague: 16th-century Portuguese gold coin, sir;
Tibalt holding up gold.
'Tis excellent meat, with sour sauce.
And here's two chains; suppose them sausages.
Then there wants wants: lacks mustard,
But the fearful Surgeon will supply ye presently.
Oh for that Surgeon! I shall die else.
Faith, there he lies in the same pickle pickle: an unpleasant situation, too.
My salves salves: healing ointments for wounds or sores and all my instruments are lost.
And I am hurt and starved.
Good sir, seek for some herbs.
Here's herb graceless herb graceless: referring to herb-of-grace, another name for common rue; will that serve?
Gentlemen, will ye go to supper?
Where's the meat?
Where's the meat? What a veal voice is there What a veal voice is there: Tibalt is comparing the question of the crew members to the bawling of calves.
Would we had it, sir, or anything else.
I would now cut your throat, you dog,
But that I would not do you such a courtesy
To take you from the benefit of starving.
Oh! What a comfort will your worship have, some three days hence!
Yea, things beneath pity shall be your harbinger harbinger: one who provides lodgings; a host.
You must not look for down-beds here,
Nor hangings hangings: curtains, though I could wish ye strong ones strong ones: i.e. strong halters for hanging and providing quick death (Bourne).

Yet here be many lightsome lightsome: graceful, elegant, cool, star-chambers star-chambers: the open air; also, a reference to the English court established in the 15th century to try socially and politically important defendants—
Open to every sweet air, I'll assure ye—
Ready provided for ye. And so I'll leave ye:
Your first course is served; expect the second.
A vengeance on these jewels.
Oh! This cursed gold!

Banerjee, Rita. "Gold, Land, and Labor: Ideologies of Colonization and Rewriting 'The Tempest' in 1622." Studies in Philology, vol. 110, no. 2 (2013): pp. 291–317.

Bourne, Claire M. L., ed. Fletcher, John, and Philip Massinger, 'A Wife for a Month,' in. The Routledge Anthology of Early Modern Drama, gen ed. edited by Claire M. L. Bourne and Jeremy Lopez, (Routledge, 2020).
de Oliveira Marques, António, Henrique R. History of Portugal (Columbia University Press, 1972).
Dessen, Alan C., and Leslie Thomson. A Dictionary of Stage Directions in English Drama, 1580-1642. (Cambridge University Press, 1999).

Foreman, Amanda. "The Amazon Women: Is there any truth behind the myth." Smithsonian Magazine (April 2014). Available online: https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/amazon-women-there-any-truth-behind-myth-180950188/.
Habakkuk, H. J. "Marriage Settlements in the Eighteenth Century." Transactions of the Royal Historical Society 32 (1950): 15–30.

Jackson, MacDonald P. “The Revenger’s Tragedy (1607) in Taylor, Gary, and John Lavagnino. Thomas Middleton and Early Modern Textual Culture: A Companion to The Collected Works, eds Taylor, Gary, and John Lavagnino. (Oxford, 2007), 548-61.
Jowitt, Claire. "'Her flesh must serve you': Gender, Commerce and the New World in Fletcher's and Massinger's A Wife for a Month and Massinger's The City Madam." Parergon 18.3 (2001): p. 93-117.
Lublin, Robert I. Costuming the Shakespearean Stage: Visual Codes of Representation in Early Modern Theatre and Culture. PhD dissertation. The Ohio State University, 2003.
McInnis, David. Mind-Travelling and Voyage Drama in Early Modern England. (Palgrave Macmillan, 2013).

Moore, Gaywyn Patricia, and Andrea Bernadette. "English Women, Romance, and Global Travel in Thomas Heywood's The Fair Maid of the West, Part 1," in Travel and Travail: Early Modern Women, English Drama, and the Wider World, edited by Patricia Akhimie and Andrea Bernadette (University of Nebraska Press, 2019), p. 313-30.
Narayanan, M. G. S. Calicut: The City of Truth. (Calicut University Publications, 2006).
O'Brien, Jane. "Shakespeare's Evolving Attitudes towards Women." BBC News, 27 April, 2015. Available online: www.bbc.com/news/magazine-32379759.
Schecter, John M. "Adufe." Grove Music Online. Available online: https://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/grovemusic/view/10.1093/gmo/9781561592630.001.0001/omo-9781561592630-e-4002232233.
Squadrilli, Luciana. "What Is Bottarga?" Great Italian Chefs, 23 Nov. 2019. Available on line: https://www.greatitalianchefs.com/features/what-is-bottarga.
Strabo. Geography. Book 11, Chapter 5, Section 1 (Loeb Classical Library, 1928). Available online: http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Strabo/11E*.html.
Sugg, Richard. "Medicinal Cannibalism in Early Modern Literature and Culture." Literature Compass 10.11 (2013): 825-835.
Syme, Holger Schott. Theatre and Testimony in Shakespeare's England: A Culture of Mediation. (Cambridge University Press, 2014).
Syme, Holger Schott. "The Theatre of Shakespeare's Time." The Norton Shakespeare, 3rd ed., edited by Stephen Greenblatt, et al (W. W. Norton, 2015), 93-118.
Thomson, Leslie. "The Meaning of 'Thunder and Lightning': Stage Directions and Audience Expectations." Early Theatre 2 (1999): 11-24.
Williams, Gordon. A Dictionary of Sexual Language and Imagery in Shakespearean and Stuart Literature. (The Athlone Press, 1994).

interpGrp.interp: Words or phrases related to food/drink or eating/drinking.
Words or phrases that refer to objects present on stage.
Words or phrases related to places, including specific geographic locations, that characters are, have been, or imagine going.
Words or phrases related to religion or spiritual practices.
Words or phrases that are names or represent people.
